text: Claude Code is quickly becoming the go-to AI coding assistant for many developers and also non-developers. But it's had so many updates recently like custom status lines, background tasks, and output styles that if you're not following Boris or Cat on social media, then there is a chance you might have missed it. So, let's go through them. And before we do, make sure you hit that subscribe button. First up is creating a custom status line to add contextual information below the input prompt. And it also updates your settings.json file. This is a good start, but what's much better is to add a prompt after the status line command, making sure the status line config is in a separate file. Note the first line of the standard out becomes the status line text and the status line code receives this structured JSON data whenever the conversation message updates and this is the result of the previous prompt. You can also add a padding value which will move the status line away from the edges. Next is background command which lets you run any bash command in the background by either pressing Ctrl +B which then shows over here or if you're lucky clause code will do it for you automatically. You can press the down arrow and enter to view the running background command or you can run the bashes command. From here we can view the standard out and because Claude can read it as well. This is useful for fixing issues or just asking questions. So if you use bun or have another way of sending browser logs to the terminal, this will save you a lot of time copying and pasting. And remember to press K to kill a background task because if you quit Claude's code without doing that, the application will still run. And then we have output styles which changes the way Claude communicates with you. This can be changed with the output style command where you can change from the default to explanatory which adds an educational insight section or learning which also adds insights but then adds these to-do human comments in the code and gives you tasks you have to complete before it continues which I guess is a nice way to keep your coding skills sharp.
